12706 
12707 cdef np.PyUFuncGenericFunction ufunc_shichi_loops[4]
12708 cdef void *ufunc_shichi_ptr[8]
12709 cdef void *ufunc_shichi_data[4]
12710 cdef char ufunc_shichi_types[12]
12711 cdef char *ufunc_shichi_doc = (
12712     "shichi(x, out=None)\n"
12713     "\n"
12714     "Hyperbolic sine and cosine integrals.\n"
12715     "\n"
12716     "The hyperbolic sine integral is\n"
12717     "\n"
12718     ".. math::\n"
12719     "\n"
12720     "  \\int_0^x \\frac{\\sinh{t}}{t}dt\n"
12721     "\n"
12722     "and the hyperbolic cosine integral is\n"
12723     "\n"
12724     ".. math::\n"
12725     "\n"
12726     "  \\gamma + \\log(x) + \\int_0^x \\frac{\\cosh{t} - 1}{t} dt\n"
12727     "\n"
12728     "where :math:`\\gamma` is Euler's constant and :math:`\\log` is the\n"
12729     "principal branch of the logarithm [1]_.\n"
12730     "\n"
12731     "Parameters\n"
12732     "----------\n"
12733     "x : array_like\n"
12734     "    Real or complex points at which to compute the hyperbolic sine\n"
12735     "    and cosine integrals.\n"
12736     "out : tuple of ndarray, optional\n"
12737     "    Optional output arrays for the function results\n"
12738     "\n"
12739     "Returns\n"
12740     "-------\n"
12741     "si : scalar or ndarray\n"
12742     "    Hyperbolic sine integral at ``x``\n"
12743     "ci : scalar or ndarray\n"
12744     "    Hyperbolic cosine integral at ``x``\n"
12745     "\n"
12746     "See Also\n"
12747     "--------\n"
12748     "sici : Sine and cosine integrals.\n"
12749     "exp1 : Exponential integral E1.\n"
12750     "expi : Exponential integral Ei.\n"
12751     "\n"
12752     "Notes\n"
12753     "-----\n"
12754     "For real arguments with ``x < 0``, ``chi`` is the real part of the\n"
12755     "hyperbolic cosine integral. For such points ``chi(x)`` and ``chi(x\n"
12756     "+ 0j)`` differ by a factor of ``1j*pi``.\n"
12757     "\n"
12758     "For real arguments the function is computed by calling Cephes'\n"
12759     "[2]_ *shichi* routine. For complex arguments the algorithm is based\n"
12760     "on Mpmath's [3]_ *shi* and *chi* routines.\n"
12761     "\n"
12762     "References\n"
12763     "----------\n"
12764     ".. [1] Milton Abramowitz and Irene A. Stegun, eds.\n"
12765     "       Handbook of Mathematical Functions with Formulas,\n"
12766     "       Graphs, and Mathematical Tables. New York: Dover, 1972.\n"
12767     "       (See Section 5.2.)\n"
12768     ".. [2] Cephes Mathematical Functions Library,\n"
12769     "       http://www.netlib.org/cephes/\n"
12770     ".. [3] Fredrik Johansson and others.\n"
12771     "       \"mpmath: a Python library for arbitrary-precision floating-point\n"
12772     "       arithmetic\" (Version 0.19) http://mpmath.org/\n"
12773     "\n"
12774     "Examples\n"
12775     "--------\n"
12776     ">>> import numpy as np\n"
12777     ">>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n"
12778     ">>> from scipy.special import shichi, sici\n"
12779     "\n"
12780     "`shichi` accepts real or complex input:\n"
12781     "\n"
12782     ">>> shichi(0.5)\n"
12783     "(0.5069967498196671, -0.05277684495649357)\n"
12784     ">>> shichi(0.5 + 2.5j)\n"
12785     "((0.11772029666668238+1.831091777729851j),\n"
12786     " (0.29912435887648825+1.7395351121166562j))\n"
12787     "\n"
12788     "The hyperbolic sine and cosine integrals Shi(z) and Chi(z) are\n"
12789     "related to the sine and cosine integrals Si(z) and Ci(z) by\n"
12790     "\n"
12791     "* Shi(z) = -i*Si(i*z)\n"
12792     "* Chi(z) = Ci(-i*z) + i*pi/2\n"
12793     "\n"
12794     ">>> z = 0.25 + 5j\n"
12795     ">>> shi, chi = shichi(z)\n"
12796     ">>> shi, -1j*sici(1j*z)[0]            # Should be the same.\n"
12797     "((-0.04834719325101729+1.5469354086921228j),\n"
12798     " (-0.04834719325101729+1.5469354086921228j))\n"
12799     ">>> chi, sici(-1j*z)[1] + 1j*np.pi/2  # Should be the same.\n"
12800     "((-0.19568708973868087+1.556276312103824j),\n"
12801     " (-0.19568708973868087+1.556276312103824j))\n"
12802     "\n"
12803     "Plot the functions evaluated on the real axis:\n"
12804     "\n"
12805     ">>> xp = np.geomspace(1e-8, 4.0, 250)\n"
12806     ">>> x = np.concatenate((-xp[::-1], xp))\n"
12807     ">>> shi, chi = shichi(x)\n"
12808     "\n"
12809     ">>> fig, ax = plt.subplots()\n"
12810     ">>> ax.plot(x, shi, label='Shi(x)')\n"
12811     ">>> ax.plot(x, chi, '--', label='Chi(x)')\n"
12812     ">>> ax.set_xlabel('x')\n"
12813     ">>> ax.set_title('Hyperbolic Sine and Cosine Integrals')\n"
12814     ">>> ax.legend(shadow=True, framealpha=1, loc='lower right')\n"
12815     ">>> ax.grid(True)\n"
12816     ">>> plt.show()")
12817 ufunc_shichi_loops[0] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_i_d_dd_As_f_ff
12818 ufunc_shichi_loops[1] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_i_d_dd_As_d_dd
12819 ufunc_shichi_loops[2] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_i_D_DD_As_F_FF
12820 ufunc_shichi_loops[3] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_i_D_DD_As_D_DD
12821 ufunc_shichi_types[0] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
12822 ufunc_shichi_types[1] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
12823 ufunc_shichi_types[2] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
12824 ufunc_shichi_types[3] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
12825 ufunc_shichi_types[4] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
12826 ufunc_shichi_types[5] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
12827 ufunc_shichi_types[6] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
12828 ufunc_shichi_types[7] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
12829 ufunc_shichi_types[8] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
12830 ufunc_shichi_types[9] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
12831 ufunc_shichi_types[10] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
12832 ufunc_shichi_types[11] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
12833 ufunc_shichi_ptr[2*0] = <void*>_func_xsf_shichi
12834 ufunc_shichi_ptr[2*0+1] = <void*>(<char*>"shichi")
12835 ufunc_shichi_ptr[2*1] = <void*>_func_xsf_shichi
12836 ufunc_shichi_ptr[2*1+1] = <void*>(<char*>"shichi")
12837 ufunc_shichi_ptr[2*2] = <void*>_func_xsf_cshichi
12838 ufunc_shichi_ptr[2*2+1] = <void*>(<char*>"shichi")
12839 ufunc_shichi_ptr[2*3] = <void*>_func_xsf_cshichi
12840 ufunc_shichi_ptr[2*3+1] = <void*>(<char*>"shichi")
12841 ufunc_shichi_data[0] = &ufunc_shichi_ptr[2*0]
12842 ufunc_shichi_data[1] = &ufunc_shichi_ptr[2*1]
12843 ufunc_shichi_data[2] = &ufunc_shichi_ptr[2*2]
12844 ufunc_shichi_data[3] = &ufunc_shichi_ptr[2*3]
12845 shichi = np.PyUFunc_FromFuncAndData(ufunc_shichi_loops, ufunc_shichi_data, ufunc_shichi_types, 4, 1, 2, 0, "shichi", ufunc_shichi_doc, 0)
12846 
12847 cdef np.PyUFuncGenericFunction ufunc_sici_loops[4]
12848 cdef void *ufunc_sici_ptr[8]
12849 cdef void *ufunc_sici_data[4]
12850 cdef char ufunc_sici_types[12]
12851 cdef char *ufunc_sici_doc = (
12852     "sici(x, out=None)\n"
12853     "\n"
12854     "Sine and cosine integrals.\n"
12855     "\n"
12856     "The sine integral is\n"
12857     "\n"
12858     ".. math::\n"
12859     "\n"
12860     "  \\int_0^x \\frac{\\sin{t}}{t}dt\n"
12861     "\n"
12862     "and the cosine integral is\n"
12863     "\n"
12864     ".. math::\n"
12865     "\n"
12866     "  \\gamma + \\log(x) + \\int_0^x \\frac{\\cos{t} - 1}{t}dt\n"
12867     "\n"
12868     "where :math:`\\gamma` is Euler's constant and :math:`\\log` is the\n"
12869     "principal branch of the logarithm [1]_.\n"
12870     "\n"
12871     "Parameters\n"
12872     "----------\n"
12873     "x : array_like\n"
12874     "    Real or complex points at which to compute the sine and cosine\n"
12875     "    integrals.\n"
12876     "out : tuple of ndarray, optional\n"
12877     "    Optional output arrays for the function results\n"
12878     "\n"
12879     "Returns\n"
12880     "-------\n"
12881     "si : scalar or ndarray\n"
12882     "    Sine integral at ``x``\n"
12883     "ci : scalar or ndarray\n"
12884     "    Cosine integral at ``x``\n"
12885     "\n"
12886     "See Also\n"
12887     "--------\n"
12888     "shichi : Hyperbolic sine and cosine integrals.\n"
12889     "exp1 : Exponential integral E1.\n"
12890     "expi : Exponential integral Ei.\n"
12891     "\n"
12892     "Notes\n"
12893     "-----\n"
12894     "For real arguments with ``x < 0``, ``ci`` is the real part of the\n"
12895     "cosine integral. For such points ``ci(x)`` and ``ci(x + 0j)``\n"
12896     "differ by a factor of ``1j*pi``.\n"
12897     "\n"
12898     "For real arguments the function is computed by calling Cephes'\n"
12899     "[2]_ *sici* routine. For complex arguments the algorithm is based\n"
12900     "on Mpmath's [3]_ *si* and *ci* routines.\n"
12901     "\n"
12902     "References\n"
12903     "----------\n"
12904     ".. [1] Milton Abramowitz and Irene A. Stegun, eds.\n"
12905     "       Handbook of Mathematical Functions with Formulas,\n"
12906     "       Graphs, and Mathematical Tables. New York: Dover, 1972.\n"
12907     "       (See Section 5.2.)\n"
12908     ".. [2] Cephes Mathematical Functions Library,\n"
12909     "       http://www.netlib.org/cephes/\n"
12910     ".. [3] Fredrik Johansson and others.\n"
12911     "       \"mpmath: a Python library for arbitrary-precision floating-point\n"
12912     "       arithmetic\" (Version 0.19) http://mpmath.org/\n"
12913     "\n"
12914     "Examples\n"
12915     "--------\n"
12916     ">>> import numpy as np\n"
12917     ">>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n"
12918     ">>> from scipy.special import sici, exp1\n"
12919     "\n"
12920     "`sici` accepts real or complex input:\n"
12921     "\n"
12922     ">>> sici(2.5)\n"
12923     "(1.7785201734438267, 0.2858711963653835)\n"
12924     ">>> sici(2.5 + 3j)\n"
12925     "((4.505735874563953+0.06863305018999577j),\n"
12926     "(0.0793644206906966-2.935510262937543j))\n"
12927     "\n"
12928     "For z in the right half plane, the sine and cosine integrals are\n"
12929     "related to the exponential integral E1 (implemented in SciPy as\n"
12930     "`scipy.special.exp1`) by\n"
12931     "\n"
12932     "* Si(z) = (E1(i*z) - E1(-i*z))/2i + pi/2\n"
12933     "* Ci(z) = -(E1(i*z) + E1(-i*z))/2\n"
12934     "\n"
12935     "See [1]_ (equations 5.2.21 and 5.2.23).\n"
12936     "\n"
12937     "We can verify these relations:\n"
12938     "\n"
12939     ">>> z = 2 - 3j\n"
12940     ">>> sici(z)\n"
12941     "((4.54751388956229-1.3991965806460565j),\n"
12942     "(1.408292501520851+2.9836177420296055j))\n"
12943     "\n"
12944     ">>> (exp1(1j*z) - exp1(-1j*z))/2j + np.pi/2  # Same as sine integral\n"
12945     "(4.54751388956229-1.3991965806460565j)\n"
12946     "\n"
12947     ">>> -(exp1(1j*z) + exp1(-1j*z))/2            # Same as cosine integral\n"
12948     "(1.408292501520851+2.9836177420296055j)\n"
12949     "\n"
12950     "Plot the functions evaluated on the real axis; the dotted horizontal\n"
12951     "lines are at pi/2 and -pi/2:\n"
12952     "\n"
12953     ">>> x = np.linspace(-16, 16, 150)\n"
12954     ">>> si, ci = sici(x)\n"
12955     "\n"
12956     ">>> fig, ax = plt.subplots()\n"
12957     ">>> ax.plot(x, si, label='Si(x)')\n"
12958     ">>> ax.plot(x, ci, '--', label='Ci(x)')\n"
12959     ">>> ax.legend(shadow=True, framealpha=1, loc='upper left')\n"
12960     ">>> ax.set_xlabel('x')\n"
12961     ">>> ax.set_title('Sine and Cosine Integrals')\n"
12962     ">>> ax.axhline(np.pi/2, linestyle=':', alpha=0.5, color='k')\n"
12963     ">>> ax.axhline(-np.pi/2, linestyle=':', alpha=0.5, color='k')\n"
12964     ">>> ax.grid(True)\n"
12965     ">>> plt.show()")
12966 ufunc_sici_loops[0] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_i_d_dd_As_f_ff
12967 ufunc_sici_loops[1] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_i_d_dd_As_d_dd
12968 ufunc_sici_loops[2] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_i_D_DD_As_F_FF
12969 ufunc_sici_loops[3] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_i_D_DD_As_D_DD
12970 ufunc_sici_types[0] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
12971 ufunc_sici_types[1] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
12972 ufunc_sici_types[2] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
12973 ufunc_sici_types[3] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
12974 ufunc_sici_types[4] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
12975 ufunc_sici_types[5] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
12976 ufunc_sici_types[6] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
12977 ufunc_sici_types[7] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
12978 ufunc_sici_types[8] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
12979 ufunc_sici_types[9] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
12980 ufunc_sici_types[10] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
12981 ufunc_sici_types[11] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
12982 ufunc_sici_ptr[2*0] = <void*>_func_xsf_sici
12983 ufunc_sici_ptr[2*0+1] = <void*>(<char*>"sici")
12984 ufunc_sici_ptr[2*1] = <void*>_func_xsf_sici
12985 ufunc_sici_ptr[2*1+1] = <void*>(<char*>"sici")
12986 ufunc_sici_ptr[2*2] = <void*>_func_xsf_csici
12987 ufunc_sici_ptr[2*2+1] = <void*>(<char*>"sici")
12988 ufunc_sici_ptr[2*3] = <void*>_func_xsf_csici
12989 ufunc_sici_ptr[2*3+1] = <void*>(<char*>"sici")
12990 ufunc_sici_data[0] = &ufunc_sici_ptr[2*0]
12991 ufunc_sici_data[1] = &ufunc_sici_ptr[2*1]
12992 ufunc_sici_data[2] = &ufunc_sici_ptr[2*2]
12993 ufunc_sici_data[3] = &ufunc_sici_ptr[2*3]
12994 sici = np.PyUFunc_FromFuncAndData(ufunc_sici_loops, ufunc_sici_data, ufunc_sici_types, 4, 1, 2, 0, "sici", ufunc_sici_doc, 0)
12995 
12996 cdef np.PyUFuncGenericFunction ufunc_smirnov_loops[3]
12997 cdef void *ufunc_smirnov_ptr[6]
12998 cdef void *ufunc_smirnov_data[3]
12999 cdef char ufunc_smirnov_types[9]
13000 cdef char *ufunc_smirnov_doc = (
13001     "smirnov(n, d, out=None)\n"
13002     "\n"
13003     "Kolmogorov-Smirnov complementary cumulative distribution function\n"
13004     "\n"
13005     "Returns the exact Kolmogorov-Smirnov complementary cumulative\n"
13006     "distribution function,(aka the Survival Function) of Dn+ (or Dn-)\n"
13007     "for a one-sided test of equality between an empirical and a\n"
13008     "theoretical distribution. It is equal to the probability that the\n"
13009     "maximum difference between a theoretical distribution and an empirical\n"
13010     "one based on `n` samples is greater than d.\n"
13011     "\n"
13012     "Parameters\n"
13013     "----------\n"
13014     "n : int\n"
13015     "  Number of samples\n"
13016     "d : float array_like\n"
13017     "  Deviation between the Empirical CDF (ECDF) and the target CDF.\n"
13018     "out : ndarray, optional\n"
13019     "    Optional output array for the function results\n"
13020     "\n"
13021     "Returns\n"
13022     "-------\n"
13023     "scalar or ndarray\n"
13024     "    The value(s) of smirnov(n, d), Prob(Dn+ >= d) (Also Prob(Dn- >= d))\n"
13025     "\n"
13026     "See Also\n"
13027     "--------\n"
13028     "smirnovi : The Inverse Survival Function for the distribution\n"
13029     "scipy.stats.ksone : Provides the functionality as a continuous distribution\n"
13030     "kolmogorov, kolmogi : Functions for the two-sided distribution\n"
13031     "\n"
13032     "Notes\n"
13033     "-----\n"
13034     "`smirnov` is used by `stats.kstest` in the application of the\n"
13035     "Kolmogorov-Smirnov Goodness of Fit test. For historical reasons this\n"
13036     "function is exposed in `scpy.special`, but the recommended way to achieve\n"
13037     "the most accurate CDF/SF/PDF/PPF/ISF computations is to use the\n"
13038     "`stats.ksone` distribution.\n"
13039     "\n"
13040     "Examples\n"
13041     "--------\n"
13042     ">>> import numpy as np\n"
13043     ">>> from scipy.special import smirnov\n"
13044     ">>> from scipy.stats import norm\n"
13045     "\n"
13046     "Show the probability of a gap at least as big as 0, 0.5 and 1.0 for a\n"
13047     "sample of size 5.\n"
13048     "\n"
13049     ">>> smirnov(5, [0, 0.5, 1.0])\n"
13050     "array([ 1.   ,  0.056,  0.   ])\n"
13051     "\n"
13052     "Compare a sample of size 5 against N(0, 1), the standard normal\n"
13053     "distribution with mean 0 and standard deviation 1.\n"
13054     "\n"
13055     "`x` is the sample.\n"
13056     "\n"
13057     ">>> x = np.array([-1.392, -0.135, 0.114, 0.190, 1.82])\n"
13058     "\n"
13059     ">>> target = norm(0, 1)\n"
13060     ">>> cdfs = target.cdf(x)\n"
13061     ">>> cdfs\n"
13062     "array([0.0819612 , 0.44630594, 0.5453811 , 0.57534543, 0.9656205 ])\n"
13063     "\n"
13064     "Construct the empirical CDF and the K-S statistics (Dn+, Dn-, Dn).\n"
13065     "\n"
13066     ">>> n = len(x)\n"
13067     ">>> ecdfs = np.arange(n+1, dtype=float)/n\n"
13068     ">>> cols = np.column_stack([x, ecdfs[1:], cdfs, cdfs - ecdfs[:n],\n"
13069     "...                        ecdfs[1:] - cdfs])\n"
13070     ">>> with np.printoptions(precision=3):\n"
13071     "...    print(cols)\n"
13072     "[[-1.392  0.2    0.082  0.082  0.118]\n"
13073     " [-0.135  0.4    0.446  0.246 -0.046]\n"
13074     " [ 0.114  0.6    0.545  0.145  0.055]\n"
13075     " [ 0.19   0.8    0.575 -0.025  0.225]\n"
13076     " [ 1.82   1.     0.966  0.166  0.034]]\n"
13077     ">>> gaps = cols[:, -2:]\n"
13078     ">>> Dnpm = np.max(gaps, axis=0)\n"
13079     ">>> print(f'Dn-={Dnpm[0]:f}, Dn+={Dnpm[1]:f}')\n"
13080     "Dn-=0.246306, Dn+=0.224655\n"
13081     ">>> probs = smirnov(n, Dnpm)\n"
13082     ">>> print(f'For a sample of size {n} drawn from N(0, 1):',\n"
13083     "...       f' Smirnov n={n}: Prob(Dn- >= {Dnpm[0]:f}) = {probs[0]:.4f}',\n"
13084     "...       f' Smirnov n={n}: Prob(Dn+ >= {Dnpm[1]:f}) = {probs[1]:.4f}',\n"
13085     "...       sep='\\n')\n"
13086     "For a sample of size 5 drawn from N(0, 1):\n"
13087     " Smirnov n=5: Prob(Dn- >= 0.246306) = 0.4711\n"
13088     " Smirnov n=5: Prob(Dn+ >= 0.224655) = 0.5245\n"
13089     "\n"
13090     "Plot the empirical CDF and the standard normal CDF.\n"
13091     "\n"
13092     ">>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n"
13093     ">>> plt.step(np.concatenate(([-2.5], x, [2.5])),\n"
13094     "...          np.concatenate((ecdfs, [1])),\n"
13095     "...          where='post', label='Empirical CDF')\n"
13096     ">>> xx = np.linspace(-2.5, 2.5, 100)\n"
13097     ">>> plt.plot(xx, target.cdf(xx), '--', label='CDF for N(0, 1)')\n"
13098     "\n"
13099     "Add vertical lines marking Dn+ and Dn-.\n"
13100     "\n"
13101     ">>> iminus, iplus = np.argmax(gaps, axis=0)\n"
13102     ">>> plt.vlines([x[iminus]], ecdfs[iminus], cdfs[iminus], color='r',\n"
13103     "...            alpha=0.5, lw=4)\n"
13104     ">>> plt.vlines([x[iplus]], cdfs[iplus], ecdfs[iplus+1], color='m',\n"
13105     "...            alpha=0.5, lw=4)\n"
13106     "\n"
13107     ">>> plt.grid(True)\n"
13108     ">>> plt.legend(framealpha=1, shadow=True)\n"
13109     ">>> plt.show()")
13110 ufunc_smirnov_loops[0] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_pd__As_pd_d
13111 ufunc_smirnov_loops[1] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_ff_f
13112 ufunc_smirnov_loops[2] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_dd_d
13113 ufunc_smirnov_types[0] = <char>NPY_INTP
13114 ufunc_smirnov_types[1] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13115 ufunc_smirnov_types[2] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13116 ufunc_smirnov_types[3] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13117 ufunc_smirnov_types[4] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13118 ufunc_smirnov_types[5] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13119 ufunc_smirnov_types[6] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13120 ufunc_smirnov_types[7] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13121 ufunc_smirnov_types[8] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13122 ufunc_smirnov_ptr[2*0] = <void*>_func_cephes_smirnov_wrap
13123 ufunc_smirnov_ptr[2*0+1] = <void*>(<char*>"smirnov")
13124 ufunc_smirnov_ptr[2*1] = <void*>_func_smirnov_unsafe
13125 ufunc_smirnov_ptr[2*1+1] = <void*>(<char*>"smirnov")
13126 ufunc_smirnov_ptr[2*2] = <void*>_func_smirnov_unsafe
13127 ufunc_smirnov_ptr[2*2+1] = <void*>(<char*>"smirnov")
13128 ufunc_smirnov_data[0] = &ufunc_smirnov_ptr[2*0]
13129 ufunc_smirnov_data[1] = &ufunc_smirnov_ptr[2*1]
13130 ufunc_smirnov_data[2] = &ufunc_smirnov_ptr[2*2]
13131 smirnov = np.PyUFunc_FromFuncAndData(ufunc_smirnov_loops, ufunc_smirnov_data, ufunc_smirnov_types, 3, 2, 1, 0, "smirnov", ufunc_smirnov_doc, 0)
13132 
13133 cdef np.PyUFuncGenericFunction ufunc_smirnovi_loops[3]
13134 cdef void *ufunc_smirnovi_ptr[6]
13135 cdef void *ufunc_smirnovi_data[3]
13136 cdef char ufunc_smirnovi_types[9]
13137 cdef char *ufunc_smirnovi_doc = (
13138     "smirnovi(n, p, out=None)\n"
13139     "\n"
13140     "Inverse to `smirnov`\n"
13141     "\n"
13142     "Returns `d` such that ``smirnov(n, d) == p``, the critical value\n"
13143     "corresponding to `p`.\n"
13144     "\n"
13145     "Parameters\n"
13146     "----------\n"
13147     "n : int\n"
13148     "  Number of samples\n"
13149     "p : float array_like\n"
13150     "    Probability\n"
13151     "out : ndarray, optional\n"
13152     "    Optional output array for the function results\n"
13153     "\n"
13154     "Returns\n"
13155     "-------\n"
13156     "scalar or ndarray\n"
13157     "    The value(s) of smirnovi(n, p), the critical values.\n"
13158     "\n"
13159     "See Also\n"
13160     "--------\n"
13161     "smirnov : The Survival Function (SF) for the distribution\n"
13162     "scipy.stats.ksone : Provides the functionality as a continuous distribution\n"
13163     "kolmogorov, kolmogi : Functions for the two-sided distribution\n"
13164     "scipy.stats.kstwobign : Two-sided Kolmogorov-Smirnov distribution, large n\n"
13165     "\n"
13166     "Notes\n"
13167     "-----\n"
13168     "`smirnov` is used by `stats.kstest` in the application of the\n"
13169     "Kolmogorov-Smirnov Goodness of Fit test. For historical reasons this\n"
13170     "function is exposed in `scpy.special`, but the recommended way to achieve\n"
13171     "the most accurate CDF/SF/PDF/PPF/ISF computations is to use the\n"
13172     "`stats.ksone` distribution.\n"
13173     "\n"
13174     "Examples\n"
13175     "--------\n"
13176     ">>> from scipy.special import smirnovi, smirnov\n"
13177     "\n"
13178     ">>> n = 24\n"
13179     ">>> deviations = [0.1, 0.2, 0.3]\n"
13180     "\n"
13181     "Use `smirnov` to compute the complementary CDF of the Smirnov\n"
13182     "distribution for the given number of samples and deviations.\n"
13183     "\n"
13184     ">>> p = smirnov(n, deviations)\n"
13185     ">>> p\n"
13186     "array([0.58105083, 0.12826832, 0.01032231])\n"
13187     "\n"
13188     "The inverse function ``smirnovi(n, p)`` returns ``deviations``.\n"
13189     "\n"
13190     ">>> smirnovi(n, p)\n"
13191     "array([0.1, 0.2, 0.3])")
13192 ufunc_smirnovi_loops[0] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_pd__As_pd_d
13193 ufunc_smirnovi_loops[1] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_ff_f
13194 ufunc_smirnovi_loops[2] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_dd_d
13195 ufunc_smirnovi_types[0] = <char>NPY_INTP
13196 ufunc_smirnovi_types[1] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13197 ufunc_smirnovi_types[2] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13198 ufunc_smirnovi_types[3] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13199 ufunc_smirnovi_types[4] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13200 ufunc_smirnovi_types[5] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13201 ufunc_smirnovi_types[6] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13202 ufunc_smirnovi_types[7] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13203 ufunc_smirnovi_types[8] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13204 ufunc_smirnovi_ptr[2*0] = <void*>_func_cephes_smirnovi_wrap
13205 ufunc_smirnovi_ptr[2*0+1] = <void*>(<char*>"smirnovi")
13206 ufunc_smirnovi_ptr[2*1] = <void*>_func_smirnovi_unsafe
13207 ufunc_smirnovi_ptr[2*1+1] = <void*>(<char*>"smirnovi")
13208 ufunc_smirnovi_ptr[2*2] = <void*>_func_smirnovi_unsafe
13209 ufunc_smirnovi_ptr[2*2+1] = <void*>(<char*>"smirnovi")
13210 ufunc_smirnovi_data[0] = &ufunc_smirnovi_ptr[2*0]
13211 ufunc_smirnovi_data[1] = &ufunc_smirnovi_ptr[2*1]
13212 ufunc_smirnovi_data[2] = &ufunc_smirnovi_ptr[2*2]
13213 smirnovi = np.PyUFunc_FromFuncAndData(ufunc_smirnovi_loops, ufunc_smirnovi_data, ufunc_smirnovi_types, 3, 2, 1, 0, "smirnovi", ufunc_smirnovi_doc, 0)
13214 
13215 cdef np.PyUFuncGenericFunction ufunc_spence_loops[4]
13216 cdef void *ufunc_spence_ptr[8]
13217 cdef void *ufunc_spence_data[4]
13218 cdef char ufunc_spence_types[8]
13219 cdef char *ufunc_spence_doc = (
13220     "spence(z, out=None)\n"
13221     "\n"
13222     "Spence's function, also known as the dilogarithm.\n"
13223     "\n"
13224     "It is defined to be\n"
13225     "\n"
13226     ".. math::\n"
13227     "  \\int_1^z \\frac{\\log(t)}{1 - t}dt\n"
13228     "\n"
13229     "for complex :math:`z`, where the contour of integration is taken\n"
13230     "to avoid the branch cut of the logarithm. Spence's function is\n"
13231     "analytic everywhere except the negative real axis where it has a\n"
13232     "branch cut.\n"
13233     "\n"
13234     "Parameters\n"
13235     "----------\n"
13236     "z : array_like\n"
13237     "    Points at which to evaluate Spence's function\n"
13238     "out : ndarray, optional\n"
13239     "    Optional output array for the function results\n"
13240     "\n"
13241     "Returns\n"
13242     "-------\n"
13243     "s : scalar or ndarray\n"
13244     "    Computed values of Spence's function\n"
13245     "\n"
13246     "Notes\n"
13247     "-----\n"
13248     "There is a different convention which defines Spence's function by\n"
13249     "the integral\n"
13250     "\n"
13251     ".. math::\n"
13252     "  -\\int_0^z \\frac{\\log(1 - t)}{t}dt;\n"
13253     "\n"
13254     "this is our ``spence(1 - z)``.\n"
13255     "\n"
13256     "Examples\n"
13257     "--------\n"
13258     ">>> import numpy as np\n"
13259     ">>> from scipy.special import spence\n"
13260     ">>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n"
13261     "\n"
13262     "The function is defined for complex inputs:\n"
13263     "\n"
13264     ">>> spence([1-1j, 1.5+2j, 3j, -10-5j])\n"
13265     "array([-0.20561676+0.91596559j, -0.86766909-1.39560134j,\n"
13266     "       -0.59422064-2.49129918j, -1.14044398+6.80075924j])\n"
13267     "\n"
13268     "For complex inputs on the branch cut, which is the negative real axis,\n"
13269     "the function returns the limit for ``z`` with positive imaginary part.\n"
13270     "For example, in the following, note the sign change of the imaginary\n"
13271     "part of the output for ``z = -2`` and ``z = -2 - 1e-8j``:\n"
13272     "\n"
13273     ">>> spence([-2 + 1e-8j, -2, -2 - 1e-8j])\n"
13274     "array([2.32018041-3.45139229j, 2.32018042-3.4513923j ,\n"
13275     "       2.32018041+3.45139229j])\n"
13276     "\n"
13277     "The function returns ``nan`` for real inputs on the branch cut:\n"
13278     "\n"
13279     ">>> spence(-1.5)\n"
13280     "nan\n"
13281     "\n"
13282     "Verify some particular values: ``spence(0) = pi**2/6``,\n"
13283     "``spence(1) = 0`` and ``spence(2) = -pi**2/12``.\n"
13284     "\n"
13285     ">>> spence([0, 1, 2])\n"
13286     "array([ 1.64493407,  0.        , -0.82246703])\n"
13287     ">>> np.pi**2/6, -np.pi**2/12\n"
13288     "(1.6449340668482264, -0.8224670334241132)\n"
13289     "\n"
13290     "Verify the identity::\n"
13291     "\n"
13292     "    spence(z) + spence(1 - z) = pi**2/6 - log(z)*log(1 - z)\n"
13293     "\n"
13294     ">>> z = 3 + 4j\n"
13295     ">>> spence(z) + spence(1 - z)\n"
13296     "(-2.6523186143876067+1.8853470951513935j)\n"
13297     ">>> np.pi**2/6 - np.log(z)*np.log(1 - z)\n"
13298     "(-2.652318614387606+1.885347095151394j)\n"
13299     "\n"
13300     "Plot the function for positive real input.\n"
13301     "\n"
13302     ">>> fig, ax = plt.subplots()\n"
13303     ">>> x = np.linspace(0, 6, 400)\n"
13304     ">>> ax.plot(x, spence(x))\n"
13305     ">>> ax.grid()\n"
13306     ">>> ax.set_xlabel('x')\n"
13307     ">>> ax.set_title('spence(x)')\n"
13308     ">>> plt.show()")
13309 ufunc_spence_loops[0] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_d__As_f_f
13310 ufunc_spence_loops[1] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_d__As_d_d
13311 ufunc_spence_loops[2] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_D_D__As_F_F
13312 ufunc_spence_loops[3] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_D_D__As_D_D
13313 ufunc_spence_types[0] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13314 ufunc_spence_types[1] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13315 ufunc_spence_types[2] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13316 ufunc_spence_types[3] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13317 ufunc_spence_types[4] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
13318 ufunc_spence_types[5] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
13319 ufunc_spence_types[6] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
13320 ufunc_spence_types[7] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
13321 ufunc_spence_ptr[2*0] = <void*>_func_cephes_spence
13322 ufunc_spence_ptr[2*0+1] = <void*>(<char*>"spence")
13323 ufunc_spence_ptr[2*1] = <void*>_func_cephes_spence
13324 ufunc_spence_ptr[2*1+1] = <void*>(<char*>"spence")
13325 ufunc_spence_ptr[2*2] = <void*>_func_cspence
13326 ufunc_spence_ptr[2*2+1] = <void*>(<char*>"spence")
13327 ufunc_spence_ptr[2*3] = <void*>_func_cspence
13328 ufunc_spence_ptr[2*3+1] = <void*>(<char*>"spence")
13329 ufunc_spence_data[0] = &ufunc_spence_ptr[2*0]
13330 ufunc_spence_data[1] = &ufunc_spence_ptr[2*1]
13331 ufunc_spence_data[2] = &ufunc_spence_ptr[2*2]
13332 ufunc_spence_data[3] = &ufunc_spence_ptr[2*3]
13333 spence = np.PyUFunc_FromFuncAndData(ufunc_spence_loops, ufunc_spence_data, ufunc_spence_types, 4, 1, 1, 0, "spence", ufunc_spence_doc, 0)
13334 
13335 cdef np.PyUFuncGenericFunction ufunc_stdtr_loops[2]
13336 cdef void *ufunc_stdtr_ptr[4]
13337 cdef void *ufunc_stdtr_data[2]
13338 cdef char ufunc_stdtr_types[6]
13339 cdef char *ufunc_stdtr_doc = (
13340     "stdtr(df, t, out=None)\n"
13341     "\n"
13342     "Student t distribution cumulative distribution function\n"
13343     "\n"
13344     "Returns the integral:\n"
13345     "\n"
13346     ".. math::\n"
13347     "    \\frac{\\Gamma((df+1)/2)}{\\sqrt{\\pi df} \\Gamma(df/2)}\n"
13348     "    \\int_{-\\infty}^t (1+x^2/df)^{-(df+1)/2}\\, dx\n"
13349     "\n"
13350     "Parameters\n"
13351     "----------\n"
13352     "df : array_like\n"
13353     "    Degrees of freedom\n"
13354     "t : array_like\n"
13355     "    Upper bound of the integral\n"
13356     "out : ndarray, optional\n"
13357     "    Optional output array for the function results\n"
13358     "\n"
13359     "Returns\n"
13360     "-------\n"
13361     "scalar or ndarray\n"
13362     "    Value of the Student t CDF at t\n"
13363     "\n"
13364     "See Also\n"
13365     "--------\n"
13366     "stdtridf : inverse of stdtr with respect to `df`\n"
13367     "stdtrit : inverse of stdtr with respect to `t`\n"
13368     "scipy.stats.t : student t distribution\n"
13369     "\n"
13370     "Notes\n"
13371     "-----\n"
13372     "The student t distribution is also available as `scipy.stats.t`.\n"
13373     "Calling `stdtr` directly can improve performance compared to the\n"
13374     "``cdf`` method of `scipy.stats.t` (see last example below).\n"
13375     "\n"
13376     "Examples\n"
13377     "--------\n"
13378     "Calculate the function for ``df=3`` at ``t=1``.\n"
13379     "\n"
13380     ">>> import numpy as np\n"
13381     ">>> from scipy.special import stdtr\n"
13382     ">>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n"
13383     ">>> stdtr(3, 1)\n"
13384     "0.8044988905221148\n"
13385     "\n"
13386     "Plot the function for three different degrees of freedom.\n"
13387     "\n"
13388     ">>> x = np.linspace(-10, 10, 1000)\n"
13389     ">>> fig, ax = plt.subplots()\n"
13390     ">>> parameters = [(1, \"solid\"), (3, \"dashed\"), (10, \"dotted\")]\n"
13391     ">>> for (df, linestyle) in parameters:\n"
13392     "...     ax.plot(x, stdtr(df, x), ls=linestyle, label=f\"$df={df}$\")\n"
13393     ">>> ax.legend()\n"
13394     ">>> ax.set_title(\"Student t distribution cumulative distribution function\")\n"
13395     ">>> plt.show()\n"
13396     "\n"
13397     "The function can be computed for several degrees of freedom at the same\n"
13398     "time by providing a NumPy array or list for `df`:\n"
13399     "\n"
13400     ">>> stdtr([1, 2, 3], 1)\n"
13401     "array([0.75      , 0.78867513, 0.80449889])\n"
13402     "\n"
13403     "It is possible to calculate the function at several points for several\n"
13404     "different degrees of freedom simultaneously by providing arrays for `df`\n"
13405     "and `t` with shapes compatible for broadcasting. Compute `stdtr` at\n"
13406     "4 points for 3 degrees of freedom resulting in an array of shape 3x4.\n"
13407     "\n"
13408     ">>> dfs = np.array([[1], [2], [3]])\n"
13409     ">>> t = np.array([2, 4, 6, 8])\n"
13410     ">>> dfs.shape, t.shape\n"
13411     "((3, 1), (4,))\n"
13412     "\n"
13413     ">>> stdtr(dfs, t)\n"
13414     "array([[0.85241638, 0.92202087, 0.94743154, 0.96041658],\n"
13415     "       [0.90824829, 0.97140452, 0.98666426, 0.99236596],\n"
13416     "       [0.93033702, 0.98599577, 0.99536364, 0.99796171]])\n"
13417     "\n"
13418     "The t distribution is also available as `scipy.stats.t`. Calling `stdtr`\n"
13419     "directly can be much faster than calling the ``cdf`` method of\n"
13420     "`scipy.stats.t`. To get the same results, one must use the following\n"
13421     "parametrization: ``scipy.stats.t(df).cdf(x) = stdtr(df, x)``.\n"
13422     "\n"
13423     ">>> from scipy.stats import t\n"
13424     ">>> df, x = 3, 1\n"
13425     ">>> stdtr_result = stdtr(df, x)  # this can be faster than below\n"
13426     ">>> stats_result = t(df).cdf(x)\n"
13427     ">>> stats_result == stdtr_result  # test that results are equal\n"
13428     "True")
13429 ufunc_stdtr_loops[0] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_ff_f
13430 ufunc_stdtr_loops[1] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_dd_d
13431 ufunc_stdtr_types[0] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13432 ufunc_stdtr_types[1] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13433 ufunc_stdtr_types[2] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13434 ufunc_stdtr_types[3] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13435 ufunc_stdtr_types[4] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13436 ufunc_stdtr_types[5] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13437 ufunc_stdtr_ptr[2*0] = <void*>_func_stdtr
13438 ufunc_stdtr_ptr[2*0+1] = <void*>(<char*>"stdtr")
13439 ufunc_stdtr_ptr[2*1] = <void*>_func_stdtr
13440 ufunc_stdtr_ptr[2*1+1] = <void*>(<char*>"stdtr")
13441 ufunc_stdtr_data[0] = &ufunc_stdtr_ptr[2*0]
13442 ufunc_stdtr_data[1] = &ufunc_stdtr_ptr[2*1]
13443 stdtr = np.PyUFunc_FromFuncAndData(ufunc_stdtr_loops, ufunc_stdtr_data, ufunc_stdtr_types, 2, 2, 1, 0, "stdtr", ufunc_stdtr_doc, 0)
13444 
13445 cdef np.PyUFuncGenericFunction ufunc_stdtridf_loops[2]
13446 cdef void *ufunc_stdtridf_ptr[4]
13447 cdef void *ufunc_stdtridf_data[2]
13448 cdef char ufunc_stdtridf_types[6]
13449 cdef char *ufunc_stdtridf_doc = (
13450     "stdtridf(p, t, out=None)\n"
13451     "\n"
13452     "Inverse of `stdtr` vs df\n"
13453     "\n"
13454     "Returns the argument df such that stdtr(df, t) is equal to `p`.\n"
13455     "\n"
13456     "Parameters\n"
13457     "----------\n"
13458     "p : array_like\n"
13459     "    Probability\n"
13460     "t : array_like\n"
13461     "    Upper bound of the integral\n"
13462     "out : ndarray, optional\n"
13463     "    Optional output array for the function results\n"
13464     "\n"
13465     "Returns\n"
13466     "-------\n"
13467     "df : scalar or ndarray\n"
13468     "    Value of `df` such that ``stdtr(df, t) == p``\n"
13469     "\n"
13470     "See Also\n"
13471     "--------\n"
13472     "stdtr : Student t CDF\n"
13473     "stdtrit : inverse of stdtr with respect to `t`\n"
13474     "scipy.stats.t : Student t distribution\n"
13475     "\n"
13476     "Examples\n"
13477     "--------\n"
13478     "Compute the student t cumulative distribution function for one\n"
13479     "parameter set.\n"
13480     "\n"
13481     ">>> from scipy.special import stdtr, stdtridf\n"
13482     ">>> df, x = 5, 2\n"
13483     ">>> cdf_value = stdtr(df, x)\n"
13484     ">>> cdf_value\n"
13485     "0.9490302605850709\n"
13486     "\n"
13487     "Verify that `stdtridf` recovers the original value for `df` given\n"
13488     "the CDF value and `x`.\n"
13489     "\n"
13490     ">>> stdtridf(cdf_value, x)\n"
13491     "5.0")
13492 ufunc_stdtridf_loops[0] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_ff_f
13493 ufunc_stdtridf_loops[1] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_dd_d
13494 ufunc_stdtridf_types[0] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13495 ufunc_stdtridf_types[1] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13496 ufunc_stdtridf_types[2] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13497 ufunc_stdtridf_types[3] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13498 ufunc_stdtridf_types[4] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13499 ufunc_stdtridf_types[5] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13500 ufunc_stdtridf_ptr[2*0] = <void*>_func_stdtridf
13501 ufunc_stdtridf_ptr[2*0+1] = <void*>(<char*>"stdtridf")
13502 ufunc_stdtridf_ptr[2*1] = <void*>_func_stdtridf
13503 ufunc_stdtridf_ptr[2*1+1] = <void*>(<char*>"stdtridf")
13504 ufunc_stdtridf_data[0] = &ufunc_stdtridf_ptr[2*0]
13505 ufunc_stdtridf_data[1] = &ufunc_stdtridf_ptr[2*1]
13506 stdtridf = np.PyUFunc_FromFuncAndData(ufunc_stdtridf_loops, ufunc_stdtridf_data, ufunc_stdtridf_types, 2, 2, 1, 0, "stdtridf", ufunc_stdtridf_doc, 0)
13507 
13508 cdef np.PyUFuncGenericFunction ufunc_stdtrit_loops[2]
13509 cdef void *ufunc_stdtrit_ptr[4]
13510 cdef void *ufunc_stdtrit_data[2]
13511 cdef char ufunc_stdtrit_types[6]
13512 cdef char *ufunc_stdtrit_doc = (
13513     "stdtrit(df, p, out=None)\n"
13514     "\n"
13515     "The `p`-th quantile of the student t distribution.\n"
13516     "\n"
13517     "This function is the inverse of the student t distribution cumulative\n"
13518     "distribution function (CDF), returning `t` such that `stdtr(df, t) = p`.\n"
13519     "\n"
13520     "Returns the argument `t` such that stdtr(df, t) is equal to `p`.\n"
13521     "\n"
13522     "Parameters\n"
13523     "----------\n"
13524     "df : array_like\n"
13525     "    Degrees of freedom\n"
13526     "p : array_like\n"
13527     "    Probability\n"
13528     "out : ndarray, optional\n"
13529     "    Optional output array for the function results\n"
13530     "\n"
13531     "Returns\n"
13532     "-------\n"
13533     "t : scalar or ndarray\n"
13534     "    Value of `t` such that ``stdtr(df, t) == p``\n"
13535     "\n"
13536     "See Also\n"
13537     "--------\n"
13538     "stdtr : Student t CDF\n"
13539     "stdtridf : inverse of stdtr with respect to `df`\n"
13540     "scipy.stats.t : Student t distribution\n"
13541     "\n"
13542     "Notes\n"
13543     "-----\n"
13544     "The student t distribution is also available as `scipy.stats.t`. Calling\n"
13545     "`stdtrit` directly can improve performance compared to the ``ppf``\n"
13546     "method of `scipy.stats.t` (see last example below).\n"
13547     "\n"
13548     "Examples\n"
13549     "--------\n"
13550     "`stdtrit` represents the inverse of the student t distribution CDF which\n"
13551     "is available as `stdtr`. Here, we calculate the CDF for ``df`` at\n"
13552     "``x=1``. `stdtrit` then returns ``1`` up to floating point errors\n"
13553     "given the same value for `df` and the computed CDF value.\n"
13554     "\n"
13555     ">>> import numpy as np\n"
13556     ">>> from scipy.special import stdtr, stdtrit\n"
13557     ">>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n"
13558     ">>> df = 3\n"
13559     ">>> x = 1\n"
13560     ">>> cdf_value = stdtr(df, x)\n"
13561     ">>> stdtrit(df, cdf_value)\n"
13562     "0.9999999994418539\n"
13563     "\n"
13564     "Plot the function for three different degrees of freedom.\n"
13565     "\n"
13566     ">>> x = np.linspace(0, 1, 1000)\n"
13567     ">>> parameters = [(1, \"solid\"), (2, \"dashed\"), (5, \"dotted\")]\n"
13568     ">>> fig, ax = plt.subplots()\n"
13569     ">>> for (df, linestyle) in parameters:\n"
13570     "...     ax.plot(x, stdtrit(df, x), ls=linestyle, label=f\"$df={df}$\")\n"
13571     ">>> ax.legend()\n"
13572     ">>> ax.set_ylim(-10, 10)\n"
13573     ">>> ax.set_title(\"Student t distribution quantile function\")\n"
13574     ">>> plt.show()\n"
13575     "\n"
13576     "The function can be computed for several degrees of freedom at the same\n"
13577     "time by providing a NumPy array or list for `df`:\n"
13578     "\n"
13579     ">>> stdtrit([1, 2, 3], 0.7)\n"
13580     "array([0.72654253, 0.6172134 , 0.58438973])\n"
13581     "\n"
13582     "It is possible to calculate the function at several points for several\n"
13583     "different degrees of freedom simultaneously by providing arrays for `df`\n"
13584     "and `p` with shapes compatible for broadcasting. Compute `stdtrit` at\n"
13585     "4 points for 3 degrees of freedom resulting in an array of shape 3x4.\n"
13586     "\n"
13587     ">>> dfs = np.array([[1], [2], [3]])\n"
13588     ">>> p = np.array([0.2, 0.4, 0.7, 0.8])\n"
13589     ">>> dfs.shape, p.shape\n"
13590     "((3, 1), (4,))\n"
13591     "\n"
13592     ">>> stdtrit(dfs, p)\n"
13593     "array([[-1.37638192, -0.3249197 ,  0.72654253,  1.37638192],\n"
13594     "       [-1.06066017, -0.28867513,  0.6172134 ,  1.06066017],\n"
13595     "       [-0.97847231, -0.27667066,  0.58438973,  0.97847231]])\n"
13596     "\n"
13597     "The t distribution is also available as `scipy.stats.t`. Calling `stdtrit`\n"
13598     "directly can be much faster than calling the ``ppf`` method of\n"
13599     "`scipy.stats.t`. To get the same results, one must use the following\n"
13600     "parametrization: ``scipy.stats.t(df).ppf(x) = stdtrit(df, x)``.\n"
13601     "\n"
13602     ">>> from scipy.stats import t\n"
13603     ">>> df, x = 3, 0.5\n"
13604     ">>> stdtrit_result = stdtrit(df, x)  # this can be faster than below\n"
13605     ">>> stats_result = t(df).ppf(x)\n"
13606     ">>> stats_result == stdtrit_result  # test that results are equal\n"
13607     "True")
13608 ufunc_stdtrit_loops[0] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_ff_f
13609 ufunc_stdtrit_loops[1] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_dd_d
13610 ufunc_stdtrit_types[0] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13611 ufunc_stdtrit_types[1] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13612 ufunc_stdtrit_types[2] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13613 ufunc_stdtrit_types[3] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13614 ufunc_stdtrit_types[4] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13615 ufunc_stdtrit_types[5] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13616 ufunc_stdtrit_ptr[2*0] = <void*>_func_stdtrit
13617 ufunc_stdtrit_ptr[2*0+1] = <void*>(<char*>"stdtrit")
13618 ufunc_stdtrit_ptr[2*1] = <void*>_func_stdtrit
13619 ufunc_stdtrit_ptr[2*1+1] = <void*>(<char*>"stdtrit")
13620 ufunc_stdtrit_data[0] = &ufunc_stdtrit_ptr[2*0]
13621 ufunc_stdtrit_data[1] = &ufunc_stdtrit_ptr[2*1]
13622 stdtrit = np.PyUFunc_FromFuncAndData(ufunc_stdtrit_loops, ufunc_stdtrit_data, ufunc_stdtrit_types, 2, 2, 1, 0, "stdtrit", ufunc_stdtrit_doc, 0)
13623 
13624 cdef np.PyUFuncGenericFunction ufunc_tklmbda_loops[2]
13625 cdef void *ufunc_tklmbda_ptr[4]
13626 cdef void *ufunc_tklmbda_data[2]
13627 cdef char ufunc_tklmbda_types[6]
13628 cdef char *ufunc_tklmbda_doc = (
13629     "tklmbda(x, lmbda, out=None)\n"
13630     "\n"
13631     "Cumulative distribution function of the Tukey lambda distribution.\n"
13632     "\n"
13633     "Parameters\n"
13634     "----------\n"
13635     "x, lmbda : array_like\n"
13636     "    Parameters\n"
13637     "out : ndarray, optional\n"
13638     "    Optional output array for the function results\n"
13639     "\n"
13640     "Returns\n"
13641     "-------\n"
13642     "cdf : scalar or ndarray\n"
13643     "    Value of the Tukey lambda CDF\n"
13644     "\n"
13645     "See Also\n"
13646     "--------\n"
13647     "scipy.stats.tukeylambda : Tukey lambda distribution\n"
13648     "\n"
13649     "Examples\n"
13650     "--------\n"
13651     ">>> import numpy as np\n"
13652     ">>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n"
13653     ">>> from scipy.special import tklmbda, expit\n"
13654     "\n"
13655     "Compute the cumulative distribution function (CDF) of the Tukey lambda\n"
13656     "distribution at several ``x`` values for `lmbda` = -1.5.\n"
13657     "\n"
13658     ">>> x = np.linspace(-2, 2, 9)\n"
13659     ">>> x\n"
13660     "array([-2. , -1.5, -1. , -0.5,  0. ,  0.5,  1. ,  1.5,  2. ])\n"
13661     ">>> tklmbda(x, -1.5)\n"
13662     "array([0.34688734, 0.3786554 , 0.41528805, 0.45629737, 0.5       ,\n"
13663     "       0.54370263, 0.58471195, 0.6213446 , 0.65311266])\n"
13664     "\n"
13665     "When `lmbda` is 0, the function is the logistic sigmoid function,\n"
13666     "which is implemented in `scipy.special` as `expit`.\n"
13667     "\n"
13668     ">>> tklmbda(x, 0)\n"
13669     "array([0.11920292, 0.18242552, 0.26894142, 0.37754067, 0.5       ,\n"
13670     "       0.62245933, 0.73105858, 0.81757448, 0.88079708])\n"
13671     ">>> expit(x)\n"
13672     "array([0.11920292, 0.18242552, 0.26894142, 0.37754067, 0.5       ,\n"
13673     "       0.62245933, 0.73105858, 0.81757448, 0.88079708])\n"
13674     "\n"
13675     "When `lmbda` is 1, the Tukey lambda distribution is uniform on the\n"
13676     "interval [-1, 1], so the CDF increases linearly.\n"
13677     "\n"
13678     ">>> t = np.linspace(-1, 1, 9)\n"
13679     ">>> tklmbda(t, 1)\n"
13680     "array([0.   , 0.125, 0.25 , 0.375, 0.5  , 0.625, 0.75 , 0.875, 1.   ])\n"
13681     "\n"
13682     "In the following, we generate plots for several values of `lmbda`.\n"
13683     "\n"
13684     "The first figure shows graphs for `lmbda` <= 0.\n"
13685     "\n"
13686     ">>> styles = ['-', '-.', '--', ':']\n"
13687     ">>> fig, ax = plt.subplots()\n"
13688     ">>> x = np.linspace(-12, 12, 500)\n"
13689     ">>> for k, lmbda in enumerate([-1.0, -0.5, 0.0]):\n"
13690     "...     y = tklmbda(x, lmbda)\n"
13691     "...     ax.plot(x, y, styles[k], label=rf'$\\lambda$ = {lmbda:-4.1f}')\n"
13692     "\n"
13693     ">>> ax.set_title(r'tklmbda(x, $\\lambda$)')\n"
13694     ">>> ax.set_label('x')\n"
13695     ">>> ax.legend(framealpha=1, shadow=True)\n"
13696     ">>> ax.grid(True)\n"
13697     "\n"
13698     "The second figure shows graphs for `lmbda` > 0.  The dots in the\n"
13699     "graphs show the bounds of the support of the distribution.\n"
13700     "\n"
13701     ">>> fig, ax = plt.subplots()\n"
13702     ">>> x = np.linspace(-4.2, 4.2, 500)\n"
13703     ">>> lmbdas = [0.25, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5]\n"
13704     ">>> for k, lmbda in enumerate(lmbdas):\n"
13705     "...     y = tklmbda(x, lmbda)\n"
13706     "...     ax.plot(x, y, styles[k], label=fr'$\\lambda$ = {lmbda}')\n"
13707     "\n"
13708     ">>> ax.set_prop_cycle(None)\n"
13709     ">>> for lmbda in lmbdas:\n"
13710     "...     ax.plot([-1/lmbda, 1/lmbda], [0, 1], '.', ms=8)\n"
13711     "\n"
13712     ">>> ax.set_title(r'tklmbda(x, $\\lambda$)')\n"
13713     ">>> ax.set_xlabel('x')\n"
13714     ">>> ax.legend(framealpha=1, shadow=True)\n"
13715     ">>> ax.grid(True)\n"
13716     "\n"
13717     ">>> plt.tight_layout()\n"
13718     ">>> plt.show()\n"
13719     "\n"
13720     "The CDF of the Tukey lambda distribution is also implemented as the\n"
13721     "``cdf`` method of `scipy.stats.tukeylambda`.  In the following,\n"
13722     "``tukeylambda.cdf(x, -0.5)`` and ``tklmbda(x, -0.5)`` compute the\n"
13723     "same values:\n"
13724     "\n"
13725     ">>> from scipy.stats import tukeylambda\n"
13726     ">>> x = np.linspace(-2, 2, 9)\n"
13727     "\n"
13728     ">>> tukeylambda.cdf(x, -0.5)\n"
13729     "array([0.21995157, 0.27093858, 0.33541677, 0.41328161, 0.5       ,\n"
13730     "       0.58671839, 0.66458323, 0.72906142, 0.78004843])\n"
13731     "\n"
13732     ">>> tklmbda(x, -0.5)\n"
13733     "array([0.21995157, 0.27093858, 0.33541677, 0.41328161, 0.5       ,\n"
13734     "       0.58671839, 0.66458323, 0.72906142, 0.78004843])\n"
13735     "\n"
13736     "The implementation in ``tukeylambda`` also provides location and scale\n"
13737     "parameters, and other methods such as ``pdf()`` (the probability\n"
13738     "density function) and ``ppf()`` (the inverse of the CDF), so for\n"
13739     "working with the Tukey lambda distribution, ``tukeylambda`` is more\n"
13740     "generally useful.  The primary advantage of ``tklmbda`` is that it is\n"
13741     "significantly faster than ``tukeylambda.cdf``.")
13742 ufunc_tklmbda_loops[0] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_ff_f
13743 ufunc_tklmbda_loops[1] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_dd_d
13744 ufunc_tklmbda_types[0] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13745 ufunc_tklmbda_types[1] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13746 ufunc_tklmbda_types[2] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13747 ufunc_tklmbda_types[3] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13748 ufunc_tklmbda_types[4] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13749 ufunc_tklmbda_types[5] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13750 ufunc_tklmbda_ptr[2*0] = <void*>_func_xsf_tukeylambdacdf
13751 ufunc_tklmbda_ptr[2*0+1] = <void*>(<char*>"tklmbda")
13752 ufunc_tklmbda_ptr[2*1] = <void*>_func_xsf_tukeylambdacdf
13753 ufunc_tklmbda_ptr[2*1+1] = <void*>(<char*>"tklmbda")
13754 ufunc_tklmbda_data[0] = &ufunc_tklmbda_ptr[2*0]
13755 ufunc_tklmbda_data[1] = &ufunc_tklmbda_ptr[2*1]
13756 tklmbda = np.PyUFunc_FromFuncAndData(ufunc_tklmbda_loops, ufunc_tklmbda_data, ufunc_tklmbda_types, 2, 2, 1, 0, "tklmbda", ufunc_tklmbda_doc, 0)
13757 
13758 cdef np.PyUFuncGenericFunction ufunc_voigt_profile_loops[2]
13759 cdef void *ufunc_voigt_profile_ptr[4]
13760 cdef void *ufunc_voigt_profile_data[2]
13761 cdef char ufunc_voigt_profile_types[8]
13762 cdef char *ufunc_voigt_profile_doc = (
13763     "voigt_profile(x, sigma, gamma, out=None)\n"
13764     "\n"
13765     "Voigt profile.\n"
13766     "\n"
13767     "The Voigt profile is a convolution of a 1-D Normal distribution with\n"
13768     "standard deviation ``sigma`` and a 1-D Cauchy distribution with half-width at\n"
13769     "half-maximum ``gamma``.\n"
13770     "\n"
13771     "If ``sigma = 0``, PDF of Cauchy distribution is returned.\n"
13772     "Conversely, if ``gamma = 0``, PDF of Normal distribution is returned.\n"
13773     "If ``sigma = gamma = 0``, the return value is ``Inf`` for ``x = 0``,\n"
13774     "and ``0`` for all other ``x``.\n"
13775     "\n"
13776     "Parameters\n"
13777     "----------\n"
13778     "x : array_like\n"
13779     "    Real argument\n"
13780     "sigma : array_like\n"
13781     "    The standard deviation of the Normal distribution part\n"
13782     "gamma : array_like\n"
13783     "    The half-width at half-maximum of the Cauchy distribution part\n"
13784     "out : ndarray, optional\n"
13785     "    Optional output array for the function values\n"
13786     "\n"
13787     "Returns\n"
13788     "-------\n"
13789     "scalar or ndarray\n"
13790     "    The Voigt profile at the given arguments\n"
13791     "\n"
13792     "See Also\n"
13793     "--------\n"
13794     "wofz : Faddeeva function\n"
13795     "\n"
13796     "Notes\n"
13797     "-----\n"
13798     "It can be expressed in terms of Faddeeva function\n"
13799     "\n"
13800     ".. math:: V(x; \\sigma, \\gamma) = \\frac{Re[w(z)]}{\\sigma\\sqrt{2\\pi}},\n"
13801     ".. math:: z = \\frac{x + i\\gamma}{\\sqrt{2}\\sigma}\n"
13802     "\n"
13803     "where :math:`w(z)` is the Faddeeva function.\n"
13804     "\n"
13805     "References\n"
13806     "----------\n"
13807     ".. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voigt_profile\n"
13808     "\n"
13809     "Examples\n"
13810     "--------\n"
13811     "Calculate the function at point 2 for ``sigma=1`` and ``gamma=1``.\n"
13812     "\n"
13813     ">>> from scipy.special import voigt_profile\n"
13814     ">>> import numpy as np\n"
13815     ">>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n"
13816     ">>> voigt_profile(2, 1., 1.)\n"
13817     "0.09071519942627544\n"
13818     "\n"
13819     "Calculate the function at several points by providing a NumPy array\n"
13820     "for `x`.\n"
13821     "\n"
13822     ">>> values = np.array([-2., 0., 5])\n"
13823     ">>> voigt_profile(values, 1., 1.)\n"
13824     "array([0.0907152 , 0.20870928, 0.01388492])\n"
13825     "\n"
13826     "Plot the function for different parameter sets.\n"
13827     "\n"
13828     ">>> fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(8, 8))\n"
13829     ">>> x = np.linspace(-10, 10, 500)\n"
13830     ">>> parameters_list = [(1.5, 0., \"solid\"), (1.3, 0.5, \"dashed\"),\n"
13831     "...                    (0., 1.8, \"dotted\"), (1., 1., \"dashdot\")]\n"
13832     ">>> for params in parameters_list:\n"
13833     "...     sigma, gamma, linestyle = params\n"
13834     "...     voigt = voigt_profile(x, sigma, gamma)\n"
13835     "...     ax.plot(x, voigt, label=rf\"$\\sigma={sigma},\\, \\gamma={gamma}$\",\n"
13836     "...             ls=linestyle)\n"
13837     ">>> ax.legend()\n"
13838     ">>> plt.show()\n"
13839     "\n"
13840     "Verify visually that the Voigt profile indeed arises as the convolution\n"
13841     "of a normal and a Cauchy distribution.\n"
13842     "\n"
13843     ">>> from scipy.signal import convolve\n"
13844     ">>> x, dx = np.linspace(-10, 10, 500, retstep=True)\n"
13845     ">>> def gaussian(x, sigma):\n"
13846     "...     return np.exp(-0.5 * x**2/sigma**2)/(sigma * np.sqrt(2*np.pi))\n"
13847     ">>> def cauchy(x, gamma):\n"
13848     "...     return gamma/(np.pi * (np.square(x)+gamma**2))\n"
13849     ">>> sigma = 2\n"
13850     ">>> gamma = 1\n"
13851     ">>> gauss_profile = gaussian(x, sigma)\n"
13852     ">>> cauchy_profile = cauchy(x, gamma)\n"
13853     ">>> convolved = dx * convolve(cauchy_profile, gauss_profile, mode=\"same\")\n"
13854     ">>> voigt = voigt_profile(x, sigma, gamma)\n"
13855     ">>> fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(8, 8))\n"
13856     ">>> ax.plot(x, gauss_profile, label=\"Gauss: $G$\", c='b')\n"
13857     ">>> ax.plot(x, cauchy_profile, label=\"Cauchy: $C$\", c='y', ls=\"dashed\")\n"
13858     ">>> xx = 0.5*(x[1:] + x[:-1])  # midpoints\n"
13859     ">>> ax.plot(xx, convolved[1:], label=\"Convolution: $G * C$\", ls='dashdot',\n"
13860     "...         c='k')\n"
13861     ">>> ax.plot(x, voigt, label=\"Voigt\", ls='dotted', c='r')\n"
13862     ">>> ax.legend()\n"
13863     ">>> plt.show()")
13864 ufunc_voigt_profile_loops[0] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_ddd__As_fff_f
13865 ufunc_voigt_profile_loops[1] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_ddd__As_ddd_d
13866 ufunc_voigt_profile_types[0] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13867 ufunc_voigt_profile_types[1] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13868 ufunc_voigt_profile_types[2] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13869 ufunc_voigt_profile_types[3] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
13870 ufunc_voigt_profile_types[4] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13871 ufunc_voigt_profile_types[5] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13872 ufunc_voigt_profile_types[6] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13873 ufunc_voigt_profile_types[7] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
13874 ufunc_voigt_profile_ptr[2*0] = <void*>scipy.special._ufuncs_cxx._export_faddeeva_voigt_profile
13875 ufunc_voigt_profile_ptr[2*0+1] = <void*>(<char*>"voigt_profile")
13876 ufunc_voigt_profile_ptr[2*1] = <void*>scipy.special._ufuncs_cxx._export_faddeeva_voigt_profile
13877 ufunc_voigt_profile_ptr[2*1+1] = <void*>(<char*>"voigt_profile")
13878 ufunc_voigt_profile_data[0] = &ufunc_voigt_profile_ptr[2*0]
13879 ufunc_voigt_profile_data[1] = &ufunc_voigt_profile_ptr[2*1]
13880 voigt_profile = np.PyUFunc_FromFuncAndData(ufunc_voigt_profile_loops, ufunc_voigt_profile_data, ufunc_voigt_profile_types, 2, 3, 1, 0, "voigt_profile", ufunc_voigt_profile_doc, 0)
13881 
13882 cdef np.PyUFuncGenericFunction ufunc_wofz_loops[2]
13883 cdef void *ufunc_wofz_ptr[4]
13884 cdef void *ufunc_wofz_data[2]
13885 cdef char ufunc_wofz_types[4]
13886 cdef char *ufunc_wofz_doc = (
13887     "wofz(z, out=None)\n"
13888     "\n"
13889     "Faddeeva function\n"
13890     "\n"
13891     "Returns the value of the Faddeeva function for complex argument::\n"
13892     "\n"
13893     "    exp(-z**2) * erfc(-i*z)\n"
13894     "\n"
13895     "Parameters\n"
13896     "----------\n"
13897     "z : array_like\n"
13898     "    complex argument\n"
13899     "out : ndarray, optional\n"
13900     "    Optional output array for the function results\n"
13901     "\n"
13902     "Returns\n"
13903     "-------\n"
13904     "scalar or ndarray\n"
13905     "    Value of the Faddeeva function\n"
13906     "\n"
13907     "See Also\n"
13908     "--------\n"
13909     "dawsn, erf, erfc, erfcx, erfi\n"
13910     "\n"
13911     "References\n"
13912     "----------\n"
13913     ".. [1] Steven G. Johnson, Faddeeva W function implementation.\n"
13914     "   http://ab-initio.mit.edu/Faddeeva\n"
13915     "\n"
13916     "Examples\n"
13917     "--------\n"
13918     ">>> import numpy as np\n"
13919     ">>> from scipy import special\n"
13920     ">>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n"
13921     "\n"
13922     ">>> x = np.linspace(-3, 3)\n"
13923     ">>> z = special.wofz(x)\n"
13924     "\n"
13925     ">>> plt.plot(x, z.real, label='wofz(x).real')\n"
13926     ">>> plt.plot(x, z.imag, label='wofz(x).imag')\n"
13927     ">>> plt.xlabel('$x$')\n"
13928     ">>> plt.legend(framealpha=1, shadow=True)\n"
13929     ">>> plt.grid(alpha=0.25)\n"
13930     ">>> plt.show()")
13931 ufunc_wofz_loops[0] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_D_D__As_F_F
13932 ufunc_wofz_loops[1] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_D_D__As_D_D
13933 ufunc_wofz_types[0] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
13934 ufunc_wofz_types[1] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
13935 ufunc_wofz_types[2] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
13936 ufunc_wofz_types[3] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
13937 ufunc_wofz_ptr[2*0] = <void*>scipy.special._ufuncs_cxx._export_faddeeva_w
13938 ufunc_wofz_ptr[2*0+1] = <void*>(<char*>"wofz")
13939 ufunc_wofz_ptr[2*1] = <void*>scipy.special._ufuncs_cxx._export_faddeeva_w
13940 ufunc_wofz_ptr[2*1+1] = <void*>(<char*>"wofz")
13941 ufunc_wofz_data[0] = &ufunc_wofz_ptr[2*0]
13942 ufunc_wofz_data[1] = &ufunc_wofz_ptr[2*1]
13943 wofz = np.PyUFunc_FromFuncAndData(ufunc_wofz_loops, ufunc_wofz_data, ufunc_wofz_types, 2, 1, 1, 0, "wofz", ufunc_wofz_doc, 0)
13944 
13945 cdef np.PyUFuncGenericFunction ufunc_wrightomega_loops[4]
13946 cdef void *ufunc_wrightomega_ptr[8]
13947 cdef void *ufunc_wrightomega_data[4]
13948 cdef char ufunc_wrightomega_types[8]
13949 cdef char *ufunc_wrightomega_doc = (
13950     "wrightomega(z, out=None)\n"
13951     "\n"
13952     "Wright Omega function.\n"
13953     "\n"
13954     "Defined as the solution to\n"
13955     "\n"
13956     ".. math::\n"
13957     "\n"
13958     "    \\omega + \\log(\\omega) = z\n"
13959     "\n"
13960     "where :math:`\\log` is the principal branch of the complex logarithm.\n"
13961     "\n"
13962     "Parameters\n"
13963     "----------\n"
13964     "z : array_like\n"
13965     "    Points at which to evaluate the Wright Omega function\n"
13966     "out : ndarray, optional\n"
13967     "    Optional output array for the function values\n"
13968     "\n"
13969     "Returns\n"
13970     "-------\n"
13971     "omega : scalar or ndarray\n"
13972     "    Values of the Wright Omega function\n"
13973     "\n"
13974     "See Also\n"
13975     "--------\n"
13976     "lambertw : The Lambert W function\n"
13977     "\n"
13978     "Notes\n"
13979     "-----\n"
13980     ".. versionadded:: 0.19.0\n"
13981     "\n"
13982     "The function can also be defined as\n"
13983     "\n"
13984     ".. math::\n"
13985     "\n"
13986     "    \\omega(z) = W_{K(z)}(e^z)\n"
13987     "\n"
13988     "where :math:`K(z) = \\lceil (\\Im(z) - \\pi)/(2\\pi) \\rceil` is the\n"
13989     "unwinding number and :math:`W` is the Lambert W function.\n"
13990     "\n"
13991     "The implementation here is taken from [1]_.\n"
13992     "\n"
13993     "References\n"
13994     "----------\n"
13995     ".. [1] Lawrence, Corless, and Jeffrey, \"Algorithm 917: Complex\n"
13996     "       Double-Precision Evaluation of the Wright :math:`\\omega`\n"
13997     "       Function.\" ACM Transactions on Mathematical Software,\n"
13998     "       2012. :doi:`10.1145/2168773.2168779`.\n"
13999     "\n"
14000     "Examples\n"
14001     "--------\n"
14002     ">>> import numpy as np\n"
14003     ">>> from scipy.special import wrightomega, lambertw\n"
14004     "\n"
14005     ">>> wrightomega([-2, -1, 0, 1, 2])\n"
14006     "array([0.12002824, 0.27846454, 0.56714329, 1.        , 1.5571456 ])\n"
14007     "\n"
14008     "Complex input:\n"
14009     "\n"
14010     ">>> wrightomega(3 + 5j)\n"
14011     "(1.5804428632097158+3.8213626783287937j)\n"
14012     "\n"
14013     "Verify that ``wrightomega(z)`` satisfies ``w + log(w) = z``:\n"
14014     "\n"
14015     ">>> w = -5 + 4j\n"
14016     ">>> wrightomega(w + np.log(w))\n"
14017     "(-5+4j)\n"
14018     "\n"
14019     "Verify the connection to ``lambertw``:\n"
14020     "\n"
14021     ">>> z = 0.5 + 3j\n"
14022     ">>> wrightomega(z)\n"
14023     "(0.0966015889280649+1.4937828458191993j)\n"
14024     ">>> lambertw(np.exp(z))\n"
14025     "(0.09660158892806493+1.4937828458191993j)\n"
14026     "\n"
14027     ">>> z = 0.5 + 4j\n"
14028     ">>> wrightomega(z)\n"
14029     "(-0.3362123489037213+2.282986001579032j)\n"
14030     ">>> lambertw(np.exp(z), k=1)\n"
14031     "(-0.33621234890372115+2.282986001579032j)")
14032 ufunc_wrightomega_loops[0] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_d__As_f_f
14033 ufunc_wrightomega_loops[1] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_d__As_d_d
14034 ufunc_wrightomega_loops[2] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_D_D__As_F_F
14035 ufunc_wrightomega_loops[3] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_D_D__As_D_D
14036 ufunc_wrightomega_types[0] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
14037 ufunc_wrightomega_types[1] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
14038 ufunc_wrightomega_types[2] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
14039 ufunc_wrightomega_types[3] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
14040 ufunc_wrightomega_types[4] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
14041 ufunc_wrightomega_types[5] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
14042 ufunc_wrightomega_types[6] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
14043 ufunc_wrightomega_types[7] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
14044 ufunc_wrightomega_ptr[2*0] = <void*>scipy.special._ufuncs_cxx._export_wrightomega_real
14045 ufunc_wrightomega_ptr[2*0+1] = <void*>(<char*>"wrightomega")
14046 ufunc_wrightomega_ptr[2*1] = <void*>scipy.special._ufuncs_cxx._export_wrightomega_real
14047 ufunc_wrightomega_ptr[2*1+1] = <void*>(<char*>"wrightomega")
14048 ufunc_wrightomega_ptr[2*2] = <void*>scipy.special._ufuncs_cxx._export_wrightomega
14049 ufunc_wrightomega_ptr[2*2+1] = <void*>(<char*>"wrightomega")
14050 ufunc_wrightomega_ptr[2*3] = <void*>scipy.special._ufuncs_cxx._export_wrightomega
14051 ufunc_wrightomega_ptr[2*3+1] = <void*>(<char*>"wrightomega")
14052 ufunc_wrightomega_data[0] = &ufunc_wrightomega_ptr[2*0]
14053 ufunc_wrightomega_data[1] = &ufunc_wrightomega_ptr[2*1]
14054 ufunc_wrightomega_data[2] = &ufunc_wrightomega_ptr[2*2]
14055 ufunc_wrightomega_data[3] = &ufunc_wrightomega_ptr[2*3]
14056 wrightomega = np.PyUFunc_FromFuncAndData(ufunc_wrightomega_loops, ufunc_wrightomega_data, ufunc_wrightomega_types, 4, 1, 1, 0, "wrightomega", ufunc_wrightomega_doc, 0)
14057 
14058 cdef np.PyUFuncGenericFunction ufunc_xlog1py_loops[4]
14059 cdef void *ufunc_xlog1py_ptr[8]
14060 cdef void *ufunc_xlog1py_data[4]
14061 cdef char ufunc_xlog1py_types[12]
14062 cdef char *ufunc_xlog1py_doc = (
14063     "xlog1py(x, y, out=None)\n"
14064     "\n"
14065     "Compute ``x*log1p(y)`` so that the result is 0 if ``x = 0``.\n"
14066     "\n"
14067     "Parameters\n"
14068     "----------\n"
14069     "x : array_like\n"
14070     "    Multiplier\n"
14071     "y : array_like\n"
14072     "    Argument\n"
14073     "out : ndarray, optional\n"
14074     "    Optional output array for the function results\n"
14075     "\n"
14076     "Returns\n"
14077     "-------\n"
14078     "z : scalar or ndarray\n"
14079     "    Computed x*log1p(y)\n"
14080     "\n"
14081     "Notes\n"
14082     "-----\n"
14083     "\n"
14084     ".. versionadded:: 0.13.0\n"
14085     "\n"
14086     "Examples\n"
14087     "--------\n"
14088     "This example shows how the function can be used to calculate the log of\n"
14089     "the probability mass function for a geometric discrete random variable.\n"
14090     "The probability mass function of the geometric distribution is defined\n"
14091     "as follows:\n"
14092     "\n"
14093     ".. math:: f(k) = (1-p)^{k-1} p\n"
14094     "\n"
14095     "where :math:`p` is the probability of a single success\n"
14096     "and :math:`1-p` is the probability of a single failure\n"
14097     "and :math:`k` is the number of trials to get the first success.\n"
14098     "\n"
14099     ">>> import numpy as np\n"
14100     ">>> from scipy.special import xlog1py\n"
14101     ">>> p = 0.5\n"
14102     ">>> k = 100\n"
14103     ">>> _pmf = np.power(1 - p, k - 1) * p\n"
14104     ">>> _pmf\n"
14105     "7.888609052210118e-31\n"
14106     "\n"
14107     "If we take k as a relatively large number the value of the probability\n"
14108     "mass function can become very low. In such cases taking the log of the\n"
14109     "pmf would be more suitable as the log function can change the values\n"
14110     "to a scale that is more appropriate to work with.\n"
14111     "\n"
14112     ">>> _log_pmf = xlog1py(k - 1, -p) + np.log(p)\n"
14113     ">>> _log_pmf\n"
14114     "-69.31471805599453\n"
14115     "\n"
14116     "We can confirm that we get a value close to the original pmf value by\n"
14117     "taking the exponential of the log pmf.\n"
14118     "\n"
14119     ">>> _orig_pmf = np.exp(_log_pmf)\n"
14120     ">>> np.isclose(_pmf, _orig_pmf)\n"
14121     "True")
14122 ufunc_xlog1py_loops[0] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_ff_f
14123 ufunc_xlog1py_loops[1] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_dd_d
14124 ufunc_xlog1py_loops[2] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_D_DD__As_FF_F
14125 ufunc_xlog1py_loops[3] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_D_DD__As_DD_D
14126 ufunc_xlog1py_types[0] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
14127 ufunc_xlog1py_types[1] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
14128 ufunc_xlog1py_types[2] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
14129 ufunc_xlog1py_types[3] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
14130 ufunc_xlog1py_types[4] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
14131 ufunc_xlog1py_types[5] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
14132 ufunc_xlog1py_types[6] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
14133 ufunc_xlog1py_types[7] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
14134 ufunc_xlog1py_types[8] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
14135 ufunc_xlog1py_types[9] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
14136 ufunc_xlog1py_types[10] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
14137 ufunc_xlog1py_types[11] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
14138 ufunc_xlog1py_ptr[2*0] = <void*>_func_xlog1py[double]
14139 ufunc_xlog1py_ptr[2*0+1] = <void*>(<char*>"xlog1py")
14140 ufunc_xlog1py_ptr[2*1] = <void*>_func_xlog1py[double]
14141 ufunc_xlog1py_ptr[2*1+1] = <void*>(<char*>"xlog1py")
14142 ufunc_xlog1py_ptr[2*2] = <void*>_func_xlog1py[double_complex]
14143 ufunc_xlog1py_ptr[2*2+1] = <void*>(<char*>"xlog1py")
14144 ufunc_xlog1py_ptr[2*3] = <void*>_func_xlog1py[double_complex]
14145 ufunc_xlog1py_ptr[2*3+1] = <void*>(<char*>"xlog1py")
14146 ufunc_xlog1py_data[0] = &ufunc_xlog1py_ptr[2*0]
14147 ufunc_xlog1py_data[1] = &ufunc_xlog1py_ptr[2*1]
14148 ufunc_xlog1py_data[2] = &ufunc_xlog1py_ptr[2*2]
14149 ufunc_xlog1py_data[3] = &ufunc_xlog1py_ptr[2*3]
14150 xlog1py = np.PyUFunc_FromFuncAndData(ufunc_xlog1py_loops, ufunc_xlog1py_data, ufunc_xlog1py_types, 4, 2, 1, 0, "xlog1py", ufunc_xlog1py_doc, 0)
14151 
14152 cdef np.PyUFuncGenericFunction ufunc_xlogy_loops[4]
14153 cdef void *ufunc_xlogy_ptr[8]
14154 cdef void *ufunc_xlogy_data[4]
14155 cdef char ufunc_xlogy_types[12]
14156 cdef char *ufunc_xlogy_doc = (
14157     "xlogy(x, y, out=None)\n"
14158     "\n"
14159     "Compute ``x*log(y)`` so that the result is 0 if ``x = 0``.\n"
14160     "\n"
14161     "Parameters\n"
14162     "----------\n"
14163     "x : array_like\n"
14164     "    Multiplier\n"
14165     "y : array_like\n"
14166     "    Argument\n"
14167     "out : ndarray, optional\n"
14168     "    Optional output array for the function results\n"
14169     "\n"
14170     "Returns\n"
14171     "-------\n"
14172     "z : scalar or ndarray\n"
14173     "    Computed x*log(y)\n"
14174     "\n"
14175     "Notes\n"
14176     "-----\n"
14177     "The log function used in the computation is the natural log.\n"
14178     "\n"
14179     ".. versionadded:: 0.13.0\n"
14180     "\n"
14181     "Examples\n"
14182     "--------\n"
14183     "We can use this function to calculate the binary logistic loss also\n"
14184     "known as the binary cross entropy. This loss function is used for\n"
14185     "binary classification problems and is defined as:\n"
14186     "\n"
14187     ".. math::\n"
14188     "    L = 1/n * \\sum_{i=0}^n -(y_i*log(y\\_pred_i) + (1-y_i)*log(1-y\\_pred_i))\n"
14189     "\n"
14190     "We can define the parameters `x` and `y` as y and y_pred respectively.\n"
14191     "y is the array of the actual labels which over here can be either 0 or 1.\n"
14192     "y_pred is the array of the predicted probabilities with respect to\n"
14193     "the positive class (1).\n"
14194     "\n"
14195     ">>> import numpy as np\n"
14196     ">>> from scipy.special import xlogy\n"
14197     ">>> y = np.array([0, 1, 0, 1, 1, 0])\n"
14198     ">>> y_pred = np.array([0.3, 0.8, 0.4, 0.7, 0.9, 0.2])\n"
14199     ">>> n = len(y)\n"
14200     ">>> loss = -(xlogy(y, y_pred) + xlogy(1 - y, 1 - y_pred)).sum()\n"
14201     ">>> loss /= n\n"
14202     ">>> loss\n"
14203     "0.29597052165495025\n"
14204     "\n"
14205     "A lower loss is usually better as it indicates that the predictions are\n"
14206     "similar to the actual labels. In this example since our predicted\n"
14207     "probabilities are close to the actual labels, we get an overall loss\n"
14208     "that is reasonably low and appropriate.")
14209 ufunc_xlogy_loops[0] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_ff_f
14210 ufunc_xlogy_loops[1] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_dd_d
14211 ufunc_xlogy_loops[2] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_D_DD__As_FF_F
14212 ufunc_xlogy_loops[3] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_D_DD__As_DD_D
14213 ufunc_xlogy_types[0] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
14214 ufunc_xlogy_types[1] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
14215 ufunc_xlogy_types[2] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
14216 ufunc_xlogy_types[3] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
14217 ufunc_xlogy_types[4] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
14218 ufunc_xlogy_types[5] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
14219 ufunc_xlogy_types[6] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
14220 ufunc_xlogy_types[7] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
14221 ufunc_xlogy_types[8] = <char>NPY_CFLOAT
14222 ufunc_xlogy_types[9] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
14223 ufunc_xlogy_types[10] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
14224 ufunc_xlogy_types[11] = <char>NPY_CDOUBLE
14225 ufunc_xlogy_ptr[2*0] = <void*>_func_xlogy[double]
14226 ufunc_xlogy_ptr[2*0+1] = <void*>(<char*>"xlogy")
14227 ufunc_xlogy_ptr[2*1] = <void*>_func_xlogy[double]
14228 ufunc_xlogy_ptr[2*1+1] = <void*>(<char*>"xlogy")
14229 ufunc_xlogy_ptr[2*2] = <void*>_func_xlogy[double_complex]
14230 ufunc_xlogy_ptr[2*2+1] = <void*>(<char*>"xlogy")
14231 ufunc_xlogy_ptr[2*3] = <void*>_func_xlogy[double_complex]
14232 ufunc_xlogy_ptr[2*3+1] = <void*>(<char*>"xlogy")
14233 ufunc_xlogy_data[0] = &ufunc_xlogy_ptr[2*0]
14234 ufunc_xlogy_data[1] = &ufunc_xlogy_ptr[2*1]
14235 ufunc_xlogy_data[2] = &ufunc_xlogy_ptr[2*2]
14236 ufunc_xlogy_data[3] = &ufunc_xlogy_ptr[2*3]
14237 xlogy = np.PyUFunc_FromFuncAndData(ufunc_xlogy_loops, ufunc_xlogy_data, ufunc_xlogy_types, 4, 2, 1, 0, "xlogy", ufunc_xlogy_doc, 0)
14238 
14239 cdef np.PyUFuncGenericFunction ufunc_yn_loops[3]
14240 cdef void *ufunc_yn_ptr[6]
14241 cdef void *ufunc_yn_data[3]
14242 cdef char ufunc_yn_types[9]
14243 cdef char *ufunc_yn_doc = (
14244     "yn(n, x, out=None)\n"
14245     "\n"
14246     "Bessel function of the second kind of integer order and real argument.\n"
14247     "\n"
14248     "Parameters\n"
14249     "----------\n"
14250     "n : array_like\n"
14251     "    Order (integer).\n"
14252     "x : array_like\n"
14253     "    Argument (float).\n"
14254     "out : ndarray, optional\n"
14255     "    Optional output array for the function results\n"
14256     "\n"
14257     "Returns\n"
14258     "-------\n"
14259     "Y : scalar or ndarray\n"
14260     "    Value of the Bessel function, :math:`Y_n(x)`.\n"
14261     "\n"
14262     "See Also\n"
14263     "--------\n"
14264     "yv : For real order and real or complex argument.\n"
14265     "y0: faster implementation of this function for order 0\n"
14266     "y1: faster implementation of this function for order 1\n"
14267     "\n"
14268     "Notes\n"
14269     "-----\n"
14270     "Wrapper for the Cephes [1]_ routine `yn`.\n"
14271     "\n"
14272     "The function is evaluated by forward recurrence on `n`, starting with\n"
14273     "values computed by the Cephes routines `y0` and `y1`. If ``n = 0`` or 1,\n"
14274     "the routine for `y0` or `y1` is called directly.\n"
14275     "\n"
14276     "References\n"
14277     "----------\n"
14278     ".. [1] Cephes Mathematical Functions Library,\n"
14279     "       http://www.netlib.org/cephes/\n"
14280     "\n"
14281     "Examples\n"
14282     "--------\n"
14283     "Evaluate the function of order 0 at one point.\n"
14284     "\n"
14285     ">>> from scipy.special import yn\n"
14286     ">>> yn(0, 1.)\n"
14287     "0.08825696421567697\n"
14288     "\n"
14289     "Evaluate the function at one point for different orders.\n"
14290     "\n"
14291     ">>> yn(0, 1.), yn(1, 1.), yn(2, 1.)\n"
14292     "(0.08825696421567697, -0.7812128213002888, -1.6506826068162546)\n"
14293     "\n"
14294     "The evaluation for different orders can be carried out in one call by\n"
14295     "providing a list or NumPy array as argument for the `v` parameter:\n"
14296     "\n"
14297     ">>> yn([0, 1, 2], 1.)\n"
14298     "array([ 0.08825696, -0.78121282, -1.65068261])\n"
14299     "\n"
14300     "Evaluate the function at several points for order 0 by providing an\n"
14301     "array for `z`.\n"
14302     "\n"
14303     ">>> import numpy as np\n"
14304     ">>> points = np.array([0.5, 3., 8.])\n"
14305     ">>> yn(0, points)\n"
14306     "array([-0.44451873,  0.37685001,  0.22352149])\n"
14307     "\n"
14308     "If `z` is an array, the order parameter `v` must be broadcastable to\n"
14309     "the correct shape if different orders shall be computed in one call.\n"
14310     "To calculate the orders 0 and 1 for an 1D array:\n"
14311     "\n"
14312     ">>> orders = np.array([[0], [1]])\n"
14313     ">>> orders.shape\n"
14314     "(2, 1)\n"
14315     "\n"
14316     ">>> yn(orders, points)\n"
14317     "array([[-0.44451873,  0.37685001,  0.22352149],\n"
14318     "       [-1.47147239,  0.32467442, -0.15806046]])\n"
14319     "\n"
14320     "Plot the functions of order 0 to 3 from 0 to 10.\n"
14321     "\n"
14322     ">>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt\n"
14323     ">>> fig, ax = plt.subplots()\n"
14324     ">>> x = np.linspace(0., 10., 1000)\n"
14325     ">>> for i in range(4):\n"
14326     "...     ax.plot(x, yn(i, x), label=f'$Y_{i!r}$')\n"
14327     ">>> ax.set_ylim(-3, 1)\n"
14328     ">>> ax.legend()\n"
14329     ">>> plt.show()")
14330 ufunc_yn_loops[0] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_pd__As_pd_d
14331 ufunc_yn_loops[1] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_ff_f
14332 ufunc_yn_loops[2] = <np.PyUFuncGenericFunction>loop_d_dd__As_dd_d
14333 ufunc_yn_types[0] = <char>NPY_INTP
14334 ufunc_yn_types[1] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
14335 ufunc_yn_types[2] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
14336 ufunc_yn_types[3] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
14337 ufunc_yn_types[4] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
14338 ufunc_yn_types[5] = <char>NPY_FLOAT
14339 ufunc_yn_types[6] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
14340 ufunc_yn_types[7] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
14341 ufunc_yn_types[8] = <char>NPY_DOUBLE
14342 ufunc_yn_ptr[2*0] = <void*>_func_cephes_yn_wrap
14343 ufunc_yn_ptr[2*0+1] = <void*>(<char*>"yn")
14344 ufunc_yn_ptr[2*1] = <void*>_func_yn_unsafe
14345 ufunc_yn_ptr[2*1+1] = <void*>(<char*>"yn")
14346 ufunc_yn_ptr[2*2] = <void*>_func_yn_unsafe
14347 ufunc_yn_ptr[2*2+1] = <void*>(<char*>"yn")
14348 ufunc_yn_data[0] = &ufunc_yn_ptr[2*0]
14349 ufunc_yn_data[1] = &ufunc_yn_ptr[2*1]
14350 ufunc_yn_data[2] = &ufunc_yn_ptr[2*2]
14351 yn = np.PyUFunc_FromFuncAndData(ufunc_yn_loops, ufunc_yn_data, ufunc_yn_types, 3, 2, 1, 0, "yn", ufunc_yn_doc, 0)

14358 jn = jv
